author: Alberto Zamora
title: Entra en vigor aumento al salario mÃ­nimo en todo el paÃ­s | MVS Noticias
text: A partir de este 1 de enero entrÃ³ en vigor el incremento del 20 por ciento a los salarios mÃ­nimos, con lo cual se debe pagar a un trabajador que tenga este ingreso 248.93 pesos diarios y 374.89 a los que se encuentran en la Zona Libre de la Frontera Norte. La SecretarÃ­a del Trabajo destacÃ³ que aplicarÃ¡ su programa de inspecciones anual para vigilar el cumplimiento de las obligaciones laborales con naturaleza econÃ³mica, dentro de las que se encuentra el pago correcto del salario mÃ­nimo. Por ello, aquellos trabajadores que no reciban el pago correcto podrÃ¡n denunciar la irregularidad al correo centromando.dgift@stps.gob.mx, para que se verifique el cumplimiento de la obligaciÃ³n patronal de pagar lo establecido en la ley. Te podrÃ­a interesar La dependencia resaltÃ³ que, con dicho incremento, la recuperaciÃ³n del poder adquisitivo del salario mÃ­nimo acumularÃ¡ 110 por ciento entre 2018 y 2024, y cubrirÃ¡ en 1.73 veces la LÃ­nea de Pobreza por Ingresos del Consejo Nacional de EvaluaciÃ³n de la PolÃ­tica de Desarrollo Social. Asimismo, se estima que beneficiarÃ¡ de manera directa a mÃ¡s de 8.9 millones de personas trabajadoras. Te podrÃ­a interesar De acuerdo con la SecretarÃ­a, con dicho aumento MÃ©xico encabeza la lista de los paÃ­ses miembros de la OrganizaciÃ³n para la CooperaciÃ³n y el Desarrollo EconÃ³micos con el mayor crecimiento del salario mÃ­nimo en tÃ©rminos reales de 2018 a la fecha. Cabe destacar que los salarios mÃ­nimos profesionales del listado integrado por 61 profesiones, oficios y trabajos especiales deberÃ¡n reflejar su incremento del 20 por ciento a partir de este 1 de enero.

author: gqlshare
title: Pottstown Hospital nurses ratify new 3-year contract
text:
POTTSTOWN â€” After more than nine months of bargaining, the nearly 300 registered nurses at Pottstown Hospital who comprise Pottstown Nurses United overwhelmingly ratified a new 3-year contract with the hospitalâ€™s parent company, Tower Health.
The Pottstown Nurses United vote, which concluded at 8:15 p.m. Wednesday, was a decisive 96% in favor of ratification of their new three-year contract, which prioritizes nurse recruitment and retention.
Details of the new contract were not revealed.
â€œWe worked hard for a fair contract that respects the work we do, and allows us to care safely for our patients,â€ said Pottstown Nurses United President Lori Domin, RN, a longtime Med Surg Nurse. â€œWe believe we accomplished that goal. We stuck together for what we believe in, and I think that made the difference. We see this as a win for us, for our patients, and for our hospital.â€
To bring attention to the lack of a contract, members of the Pottstown Nurses United union held an informational picket and rally outside Pottstown Hospital on July 9 to enlist the public in their efforts for a new contract.
â€œWhen hospitals struggle to recruit and retain healthcare workers, itâ€™s patients who feel the consequences,â€ says PASNAP President Maureen May, R.N., a longtime NICU nurse at Temple University Hospital. â€œWhen we invest in caregivers, we are directly investing in the quality of care our patients receive.â€
Domin agreed: â€œThis contract, so long in the making, prioritizes nurse retention and wages and working conditions to attract new hires to the bedside. Itâ€™s a hard-fought win for frontline RNs and for the quality of care our community deserves!â€
â€œIt took nine long months to get here,â€ said Diana Pagnotti, RN, an Orthopedic Nurse and 8-year veteran of Pottstown Hospital, â€œbut for what it means for our patients, for our community, and for each other, it was worth it!â€
â€œTower, Pottstown Nurses United is here to stay!â€ said Sue LoBello, RN, a Med Surg Nurse and Executive Board Member of Pottstown Nurses United. â€œWe have emerged from this process stronger, with the clear understanding that when we stand together, great things happen!â€
Pottstown Nurses United is an affiliate of PASNAP, the Pennsylvania Association of Staff Nurses and Allied Professionals, which represents 11,000 frontline nurses and allied professionals across Pennsylvania and was founded 25 years ago on the conviction that patients do better when critical care staff have a voice to advocate for their patients and themselves.

author: Olivia Roks
title: MÃ©tÃ©o en Espagne : encore des orages et des pluies ces prochaines 48h
text:
Ces prochaines 48h seront encore orageuses et pluvieuses sur le sud et lâ€™est de lâ€™Espagne mais Ã©galement le Portugal.
Plus dâ€™une annÃ©e de pluies dÃ©versÃ©es en quelques heures seulement sur les rÃ©gions du sud et de lâ€™est de lâ€™Espagne. Le bilan est dramatique. Et ce nâ€™est hÃ©las pas encore fini. Ce vendredi et samedi, toujours sous lâ€™influence de la [goutte froid](https://www.rtbf.be/article/inondations-en-espagne-qu-est-ce-que-le-phenomene-dana-a-l-origine-des-pluies-diluviennes-11456821)e, deux zones orageuses accompagnÃ©es de prÃ©cipitations intenses sont encore Ã  surveiller et Ã  craindre. Lâ€™une Ã  lâ€™ouest de lâ€™Andalousie et sur lâ€™Algarve, lâ€™autre entre Valence, Barcelone et les Ã®les BalÃ©ares. Aujourdâ€™hui, la plus haute alerte, lâ€™alerte rouge, a Ã©tÃ© Ã©mise pour la rÃ©gion de Huelva. Dans la rÃ©gion de Valence et de Barcelone, câ€™est lâ€™alerte jaune qui est de circonstance. Tous les dÃ©placements sont fortement dÃ©conseillÃ©s.
Ce vendredi, sur ces rÃ©gions, il pleuvra encore prÃ¨s de 100L/m2. Les prochaines 48h, vendredi et samedi, nous pourrions atteindre 150L/m2, ce qui nâ€™est absolument pas nÃ©gligeable vu les quantitÃ©s dÃ©jÃ  tombÃ©es.

author: Scienmag
title: Three unexpected foods in alternatives to traditional plastics
text:
Future alternatives to fossil fuel-based plastics could be hiding in kitchen cabinets and waste bins. Researchers are looking to foodstuffs as starting ingredients for polymer-based materials, including coffee grounds, tomato peels and gluten. New products made from these sustainable resources are reported in three papers recently published in ACS journals. Reporters can request free access to these papers by emailing newsroom@acs.org.
Credit: Adapted from ACS Omega 2024, DOI: 10.1021/acsomega.3c05669
Future alternatives to fossil fuel-based plastics could be hiding in kitchen cabinets and waste bins. Researchers are looking to foodstuffs as starting ingredients for polymer-based materials, including coffee grounds, tomato peels and gluten. New products made from these sustainable resources are reported in three papers recently published in ACS journals. Reporters can request free access to these papers by emailing newsroom@acs.org.
- Coffee grounds to coffee tables. Researchers have created a material suitable for large-format 3D printing by mixing leftover grounds into biobased polylactic acid. As a proof of concept, the team used the plastic composite to 3D print a life-sized side table, as described in the open access journal ACS Omega.
- Tomato peels to high-tech bioplastic. A study in ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering details a tomato-based polyester plastic that remembers its previous shapes. A ring made of the yellow material was warped at a high temperature, then placed in a warm water bath set at 140 degrees Fahrenheit, where it snapped back to its original desired shape. This proof-of-concept shows how biobased polyesters could be made with an abundant agricultural and food waste.
- Gluten to a compostable composite. A team created the biobased composite by combining wheat gluten â€” sometimes added to bread dough for extra chewiness â€” and carbon fibers. The research reported in the open access journal ACS Omega illustrates how the gluten-based material had a similar strength to fossil fuel-based plastics, yet broke down within 30 days in soil and didnâ€™t impact either the germination or growth of grass seeds. The team says the design could allow future items to be molded into any shape or size.
###
The American Chemical Society (ACS) is a nonprofit organization chartered by the U.S. Congress. ACSâ€™ mission is to advance the broader chemistry enterprise and its practitioners for the benefit of Earth and all its people. The Society is a global leader in promoting excellence in science education and providing access to chemistry-related information and research through its multiple research solutions, peer-reviewed journals, scientific conferences, eBooks and weekly news periodical Chemical & Engineering News. ACS journals are among the most cited, most trusted and most read within the scientific literature; however, ACS itself does not conduct chemical research. As a leader in scientific information solutions, its CAS division partners with global innovators to accelerate breakthroughs by curating, connecting and analyzing the worldâ€™s scientific knowledge. ACSâ€™ main offices are in Washington, D.C., and Columbus, Ohio.
To automatically receive news releases from the American Chemical Society, contact newsroom@acs.org.
Note: ACS does not conduct research, but publishes and publicizes peer-reviewed scientific studies.
